children.name: to decide how good, bad etc sb/sth is
judge
children.definition: to form an opinion about a person or situation, using your knowledge, experience, and intelligence:đánh giá
examples: ▪ The changes should be judged by their results.

children.name: judge when/whether/what etc
examples: ▪ How do you judge when a house needs a new roof?
▪ 2,000 foreign and local monitors were watching to judge whether the elections were free and fair.

children.name: judge sb/sth to be sth
examples: ▪ Women judged to be at high risk for breast cancer should be examined every year.

children.name: judge (that)
examples: ▪ Some students may judge that the benefits they receive from further education are less than the costs of that education.

children.name: judge it wise/proper/dangerous etc to do sthformal
examples: ▪ Dwight judged it dangerous to navigate in darkness in these waters.

children.name: assess
children.definition: to judge how good, bad, successful etc someone or something is, especially by using a fixed set of standards.Assessis often used about measuring students’ abilities and performance :đánh giá
examples: This test provides an excellent way of assessing students’ progress.
He has written a guidebook that assesses the quality of Californian hotels.
The booklet aims to help parents assess recent educational changes.
assess the impact/extent/effectiveness etc of sth
a report to assess the impact of advertising on children
assess how/whether/what etc
The committee will continue to assess how we can improve.
The technique is being tried in classrooms to assess what effects it may have.
be assessed as sth
Many of the adults were assessed as having learning difficulties.

children.name: evaluate
children.definition: to judge how good, bad, successful etc someone or something is, especially by carefully examining all the information about them.Evaluateis often used about the work of people doing research :đánh giá
examples: There was not enough time to evaluate the information before the meeting.
The new drug is being evaluated in clinical trials.
The police force should not evaluate officers’ performance in terms of the number of arrests they make.
The data from the study is still being evaluated.
The test is used to evaluate the effects of pesticides on domestic bees.
Students provide the college with an evaluation of the courses they took at the end of each semester.
We need tocarry outa properevaluationof the new system.
They took some samples of products for evaluation.
Evaluation of this new treatment cannot take place until all the data has been collected.

children.name: evaluation[
examples: C or U] C1 a judgment about how good, useful, or successful something is:

children.name: judgment
children.definition: / judgementUK an opinion that you form, especially after thinking carefully about sth : đánh giá
examples: In my judgment, we should accept his offer.

children.name: make a judgment
examples: It's too soon to make a judgment about what the outcome will be.

children.name: form a judgment
children.definition: make a judgment
examples: I prefer to form my own judgments, rather than relying on other people's opinions.

children.name: pass judgment
children.definition: on something
examples: (= give your opinion, especially a negative one )Our aim is to help him, not to pass judgment on what he has done.

children.name: reserve judgment
children.definition: not decide your opinion before you have all the facts
examples: Why don't you reserve judgment until you have finished the book?

children.name: base a judgment on something
children.definition: make a judgment because of something
examples: His judgment was based on bad information.

children.name: a moral judgment
children.definition: based on what you think is right
examples: People are always making moral judgments about weight loss.

children.name: a snap judgment
children.definition: made quickly
examples: In my business, I often have to make snap judgments about people.

children.name: against your better judgment
children.definition: even though you think your action might be wrong
examples: I lent him the money, against my better judgment.

children.name: assessment
children.definition: a process in which you make a judgment about a person or situation, or the judgment you make: đánh giá

children.name: make an assessment
examples: I had to make a quick assessment of the situation and act accordingly.

children.name: do/carry out an assessment
examples: A teacher does a yearly assessment of each child’s progress.

children.name: a general/overall/broad assessment
children.definition: that covers the main features or parts of something, not the details
examples: The doctor must carry out a general assessment of the patient’s health.

children.name: a detailed assessment
examples: We need a detailed assessment of what this will cost.

children.name: a comprehensive assessment
children.definition: that includes all the necessary facts or details
examples: Our clients receive a comprehensive assessment of their financial affairs.

children.name: an objective assessment
children.definition: that is based on facts, not on feelings or beliefs
examples: The test results will provide an objective assessment of how much you have improved.

children.name: sb’s personal assessment
examples: What’s your personal assessment of the risks?

children.name: the assessment procedure/process
examples: Parents need to feel part of the assessment procedure.

children.name: assessment methods/techniques
examples: We recommend using a variety of assessment methods.

children.name: assessment of
examples: What’s Michael’s assessment of the situation?

children.name: critique
children.definition: an article, book, speech etc that carefully examines a subject and says what is good or bad about it: bài phên bình
examples: The speech was a devastating critique of Reagan’s economic policy.
critique of
a major new critique of his work
a critique of modern economic theory
Marx’s critique of capitalism in the 19th century

children.name: to decide whether sb is wrong to do sth
judge
children.definition: to decide whether sb is wrong to do sth - use this when you think sb hasno rightto do this:đánh giá ,xét đoán, phán xét
examples: What right does she have to judge me?
Don’t judge other people unless you want to be judged yourself.
She should do what seems right to her. It isn’t for me to judge.
judgementalUK /judgmentalUS [adj] too ready to judge and criticize other people: hay xét đoán
judgemental about
I try not to be judgmental, but if I think someone’s being stupid, I’ll say so.
The parenting class is run in an open, non-judgmental manner that lets people speak freely.
The public is often judgmental about people’s sexuality.

children.name: pass judgment
children.definition: /judgementUK  to judge sb/sth in anegativeand oftenunreasonableway:đánh giá ,xét đoán, phán xét
examples: He refused to pass judgement until all the evidence was presented.

children.name: pass judgment upon/on
examples: Society badly needs to learn not to pass judgment on people because of their background.

children.name: sit in judgement
children.definition: UK to judge whether sb’sbehaviouris good or bad - use this especially when you think sbshould notbe doing this:phán xét, xét đoán
examples: ▪ I don’t care how annoyed she is - she’s got no absolutely no right to sit in judgement.

children.name: sit in judgement on/upon/over
examples: ▪ It seems wrong that 12 white men could sit in judgment on one black woman.

children.name: to decide who is right in a quarrel
adjudicate
children.definition: formal if sb, especially a lawyer, adjudicates, they officially form a judgement about who is legally right in an argument or disagreement:
examples: The World Court adjudicates boundary disputes and commercial claims.
The Dean adjudicates any faculty disputes.
adjudicate on/upon/in/between
The owner can appeal to the court to adjudicate on the matter.
adjudicate that
The judge adjudicated that he should be released.
adjudicator[C]
Legal advisors and adjudicators were present at the trial.
an impartial adjudicator
adjudication[U]
The situation has now become so serious that any form of adjudication would be impossible.

children.name: arbitrate
children.definition: to officially judge how an argument between two opposing groups or organizations can be settled: phân xử, làm trọng tài phân xử
examples: As president of the European Council he arbitrated in an argument over cereal prices.
Most brokerage firms require customers to arbitrate disputes rather than file lawsuits.
arbitrator[C] trọng tài phân xử
She works as an arbitrator between representatives of various competing businesses.

children.name: arbitration[
examples: U] the process of judging officially who is right in an argument or disagreement, by someone who has been chosen by the opposing groups:

children.name: The dispute is going to arbitration
children.definition: sb is being asked to arbitrate

children.name: arbitrate between
examples: A committee will arbitrate between management and unions.
A local magistrate has been asked to arbitrate between farmers and conservationist groups.

children.name: arbitrate in
examples: The tribunal arbitrates in disputes.
The case has been submitted for international arbitration.
Both sides in the dispute have agreed tobinding arbitration.

children.name: go to arbitrationask sb to arbitrate
examples: Both parties agreed to go to arbitration in order to avoid more strikes by the workers.

children.name: to write your opinion of a new film, book etc
review
children.definition: to write an article in anewspaperormagazinejudging how good or bad a film, play, television programme, or book is:đánh giá
examples: Doig’s new book is reviewed on page 4.
As well as being an author, she reviews books for the Sunday papers.
review[C] B1 an article in a newspaper or magazine that judges a book, television programme, film etc:bài đánh giá
Our first English assignment was to write a book review.
Derek writesfilm/theatre/bookreviews for the newspapers.
good/bad/mixed review
The band’s new album has had very good reviews.
good good/excellent/etc reviews
The movie got good reviews.
The playgotexcellent reviews when it was first seen.
review of
Wilberforce had just written a long review of Darwin’s book.
The paper published a review of her book.
Reviewers praised Tisler’s performance.

children.name: The film opened torave reviews
children.definition: reviews that praised it a lot

children.name: reviewer[
examples: C] sb who writes articles expressingtheir opinion of a book, play, film, etc.

children.name: Eliot wrote to him after he reviewed ‘The Use of Poetry.’
examples: I only go to see films that are reviewed favourably.

children.name: write-up
children.definition: informal an article in a newspaper or magazine, that says how good or bad a new film, book, product etc is: bài phê bình
examples: Did you see Martin Amis’ write-up of the book in the Observer?
After a write-up in Yankee magazine, orders started pouring in.
The film didn’t get a very good write-up in Time Out.
The play got a reallygood write-up(= it was praised )in the press.

children.name: criticize
children.definition: (UK usuallycriticise)  to give an opinion or judgment about a book, film, etc.: đánh giá, phên bình
examples: We're a group of artists who meet to discuss ideas and criticize each other's work.

children.name: a film/art/music etc critic
examples: He became the chief music critic for the Herald Tribune.

children.name: a literary critic
children.definition: of books and other literature

children.name: a theatre criticBritish English,a theater critcicAmerican English
children.definition: of plays

children.name: a restaurant critic
children.definition: of the food, service etc in restaurants
examples: Being a restaurant critic sounds like a glamorous lifestyle.

children.name: a social critic
children.definition: of human society and its organizations
examples: Social critics have argued that television viewing decreases people's other social activities.

children.name: a critic attacks something
examples: Many critics attacked Seurat’s paintings for their lack of colour.

children.name: a critic praises something
examples: The play was highly praised by critics and the public.

children.name: a critic hails something/somebody as something
children.definition: describes someone or something as very good
examples: Critics hailed the film as a brilliant portrayal of American society at that time.

children.name: a critic pans something
children.definition: alsoa critic slates somethingBritish English
examples: (= criticizes something strongly )The television series has been panned by critics.

children.name: critical[adj]
examples: C2giving opinions or judgments on books, plays, films, etc.

children.name: His last filmwon/receivedcriticalacclaim
children.definition: was praised by film critics

children.name: The book came out last yeartogreatcritical acclaim
children.definition: critics said it was very good

children.name: Her first play was acritical success
children.definition: critics said it was good

children.name: sb’s ability to judge people or things
judgment
children.definition: /judgementUK  the ability to make sensible decisions about what to do and when to do it : óc phán đoán, óc suy xét
examples: The break-up of a serious relationship can often make us lose confidence in our own judgement.
Teachers need to have good judgement of pupils’ needs and abilities.
I’ve known him for years and I trust his judgment.

children.name: professional/personal etc judgment
examples: The minister showed a lack of political judgment.
Watch carefully anduseyourjudgment.

children.name: sound judgementgood judgement
examples: Environmental rules are developed using good information and sound judgment.

children.name: be a good judge of
children.definition: judge a person who has the knowledge to give an opinion about something or is able to decide if someone or something is good or bad: "quan tòa, thẩm phán"
examples: be a good/bad etc judge of[VP] be able to judge people or situations well, badly etc:
She’d always thought Mr Cunningham was a good judge of character.
Professional people are sometimes bad judges of their colleagues’ conduct.
She's such a bad judge of character.

children.name: "I really don't think you should have another drink." "I'll be/Let me be the judge of that(= I am able to make my own decision about that)."
of
children.definition: prepositionJUDGMENT

children.name: used after an adjective when judging someone's behaviour
examples: _It was a bit unkind of youtomention her weight.
_Thank you so much for my present. How thoughtful of you.

children.name: judging by/from
children.definition: (alsoto judge by/from)
examples: used to express the reasons why you have a particular opinion
_Judging by what he said, I think it's very unlikely that he'll be able to support your application.
judging from/by something
when you form an opinion based on a particular fact
▪ Judging from Monday night’s game, the team still has a lot of work to do.

children.name: rate
children.definition: verbJUDGE
examples: to judge the value or character of someone or something
_How do you rate himasa footballer?
_She is rated veryhighlyby the people she works for.
_informal"What do you think of her as a singer?"
"I don't really rate her (= I do not think that she is very good) ."
_I rate carsasone of the worst polluters of the environment.
_[ + object + noun ]On a scale of one to ten, I'd rate his book a five.
_Car crashes are so frequent that they don't ratea mention(= are not considered to be worth reporting) in the newspaper unless a lot of people are killed.

children.name: review
children.definition: nounTHINK AGAIN
examples: [ C or U ] when you consider something again in order to make changes to it, give an opinion of it or study it
_an annual reviewofcompany performance
_a reviewofthe year's top news stories
_Salary levels areunderreview at the moment.
_Your licence willcome up forreview every July.

children.name: rating
children.definition: noun

children.name: press
children.definition: nounNEWSPAPERS

children.name: overestimate
children.definition: verb

children.name: to think that something is or will be greater, more extreme or more important than itreally is
examples: _The benefits of nuclear technology, she said, had been grossly overestimated.
_They were forced to the conclusion that they had overestimated him/his abilities.
_I overestimated and there was a lot of food left over after the party.

children.name: view
children.definition: verbHAVE OPINION nhìn nhận, đánh giá
